body:
Hi @cebe 
Could we go for this option? http://stackoverflow.com/a/25704866
I guess it is best one comparing complexity and result

Also we can try smth like http://stackoverflow.com/a/4968835 but it is a little bit more complex
@andrewnester if the first option covers the RFC correctly I would use it. seconds looks a bit overcomplicated.
@cebe actually it doesn't cover RFC2231. I will look for some other implementations of this RFC

issue.title: When download utf8 filename via  Response::sendfile()  , filename is not correct in IE11

repository.name: yii2
repository.description: Yii 2: The Fast, Secure and Professional PHP Framework

issue.body:
Example Code

``` php
return Yii::$app->getResponse()->sendFile($filepath, $attachment->filename);
```

if $attachment->filename is "中文.txt"  <== this is chinese filename with utf8 encoded.

When I download 
- Chome & Firefox save correct filename
- IE 11 is not correct

In http://php.net/manual/en/function.header.php , yjf_victor wrote :
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1013744/16832701/0de4414e-49de-11e6-89c4-ac25a1107317.png)

So I change my code looks like:

``` php
$response = Yii::$app->getResponse()->sendFile($filepath, $attachment->filename);
$response->headers['Content-Disposition'] = 'attachment; '
        . sprintf('filename="%s"; ', rawurlencode($attachment->filename))
        . sprintf("filename*=utf-8''%s", rawurlencode($attachment->filename));
        return $response;
```

IE11 & Chrome & Filefox can download file with correct filename.

issue.title: Response::sendFile Content-Disposition header with non-ASCII filenames

repository.name: yii2
repository.description: Yii 2: The Fast, Secure and Professional PHP Framework

issue.body:
When `$attachmentName` of `Response::sendFile` method contains non-ASCII characters the method creates invalid `Content-Disposition` HTTP header (according to specification HTTP headers cannot contain non-ASCII characters). In such a case the filename must be encoded according to https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5987 (also see https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6266#section-5).

Example:

``` PHP
return \Yii::$app->getResponse()->sendFile('somepath', 'руссо туристо.txt');
```

The file "Save As..." window prompted by IE11 contains invalid file name.

rename.from: current implementation of file download does not encode UTF8 filenames correctly
rename.to: Current implementation of file download does not encode UTF8 filenames correctly

body:
So the problem is using `Yii::$app->getResponse()->xSendFile()` or `Yii::$app->getResponse()->sendFile()` or via any other file sending method with file names like `中文.txt`. Downloading it with, for example, IE11 won't show correct file name.

The issue could be solved by sending `Content-Disposition` with both fallback-name `filename="x"` (for old browsers) and utf-name `filename*=utf-8''x` for newer ones.

## fallback-name
- Causes issues if contains non-ASCII characters with codes less than 32 or more than 126.
- Causes issues if contains urlencoded characters (starting with `%`) or `%` character. Some browsers interpret `filename="X"` as urlencoded name, some aren't.
- Causes issues if contains path separator characters such as `\` or `/`.
- Since value is wrapped with `"`, it should be escaped as `\"`.

Since input could contain non-ASCII characters, fallback should be obtained by transliterating it or by other means.

## utf-name
- Causes issues if contains path separator characters such as `\` or `/`.
- Should be urlencoded since headers are ASCII-only.
- Could be omitted if it exactly matches fallback-name.

Additionally, if file name isn't specified, file system file name is used which could be in non UTF-8 encoding. In this case non-ASCII characters may be either transliterated or replaced with placeholder such as `_`.

> The issue could be solved by sending Content-Disposition with both fallback-name filename="x" (for old browsers) and utf-name filename*=utf-8''x for newer ones.

Yes, but you need a different name for fallback-name.

@samdark 

> Additionally, if file name isn't specified, file system file name is used which could be in non UTF-8 encoding. In this case non-ASCII characters may be either transliterated or replaced with placeholder such as  _ .

You can't do ANYTHING with just "file system file name": neither substitute characters in it nor encode it for use in `filename*` since encoding of provided "file system file name" is not known.

> Causes issues if contains path separator characters such as  \  or  / .

Filenames by definition cannot contain path separator characters. So might as well assume it is not present in the provided filename.
